questions.question_text:
A company's existing forward proxies support software-based TLS decryption, but are currently at 60% load just dealing with AV scanning and content analysis for
HTTP traffic. More than 70% outbound web traffic is currently encrypted. The switching and routing network infrastructure precludes adding capacity, preventing the installation of a dedicated TLS decryption system. The network firewall infrastructure is currently at 30% load and has software decryption modules that can be activated by purchasing additional license keys. An existing project is rolling out agent updates to end-user desktops as part of an endpoint security refresh.
Which of the following is the BEST way to address these issues and mitigate risks to the organization?

choices.A: Purchase the SSL, decryption license for the firewalls and route traffic back to the proxies for end-user categorization and malware analysis.
choices.D: Accept the current risk and seek possible funding approval in the next budget cycle to replace the existing proxies with ones with more capacity.
choices.C: Use an EDP solution to address the malware issue and accept the diminishing role of the proxy for URL categorization in the short team.
choices.B: Roll out application whitelisting to end-user desktops and decommission the existing proxies, freeing up network ports.

discussion.content: Is option A supposed to read TLS instead of SSL?

comments.content: From the question: "An existing project is rolling out *agent* updates to end-user desktops as part of an endpoint security refresh." Are they already using EDR? If so, there is no need to use the forward proxies for AV scanning. If not, they could include EDR with the update. This is a big deal. According to the question, forward proxies are at: "60% load just dealing with AV scanning and content analysis for HTTP traffic." Do away with that, and there is no need to purchase SSL licenses. And again: SSL is now deprecated. TLS should be used.

discussion.content:
Maybe: C. Use an EDP solution to address the malware issue and accept the diminishing role of the proxy for URL categorization in the short team? 
This would free up the proxies. Also SSL is now deprecated. TLS should be used.

comments.content: The only EDP I've encountered is an Emergency Destruction Plan.
Looks like it is EDR indeed. There are several typos in the questions and answers.

discussion.content: What is EDP? I know about EDR (Endpoint Detection & Response) and EPP (Endpoint Protection Platform). But I am not sure about EDP.
D. right. the keyword «and need to be discussed in depth before the next branch office is upgraded..».
Lessons learned report is the answer. Lessons Learned always uses hindsight rather than preparedness before the fact.

I think it is D lesson learned.

"The review should document as many facts as possible about the incident. Keep in mind that lessons-learned/after-action reviews also work well for any major organizational project, including operating system upgrades, new server deployments, firewall upgrades, and so on." 
-CompTIA Advanced Security Practitioner (CASP) CAS-003 Cert Guide

We're talking doing analysis of what happened during the last upgrade. That would be Lessons Learned. A gap analysis covers forward thinking - i.e. this is what I have and what do I need to get there.

It could be gap analysis. But I am still leaning toward lessons learned. 
Consider this definition of gap analysis: "It's a useful technique that enables you to identify the gap between your current situation and the future state that you want to be in, along with the tasks that you need to complete to close this gap."
https://www.mindtools.com/pages/article/gap-analysis.htm
That seems to me like a gap analysis would be conducted *before* the project was complete. A gap analysis seems to ask "why aren't we further along in this *uncompleted* project" whereas a lesson learned seems to ask: "what were the problems with this competed project?" 
I am not insisting lessons learned is the correct answer. I could be wrong.

comments.content: After further review I'm going with D

discussion.content: I believe this should be gap analysis. This would analyze processes to determine how they are falling short. You can use your gap analysis to help write your lessons learned, but I believe the gap analysis is first.

questions.question_text:
A threat advisory alert was just emailed to the IT security staff. The alert references specific types of host operating systems that can allow an unauthorized person to access files on a system remotely. A fix was recently published, but it requires a recent endpoint protection engine to be installed prior to running the fix.
Which of the following MOST likely need to be configured to ensure the system are mitigated accordingly? (Choose two.)

A network engineer is attempting to design-in resiliency characteristics for an enterprise network's VPN services.
If the engineer wants to help ensure some resilience against zero-day vulnerabilities exploited against the VPN implementation, which of the following decisions would BEST support this objective?

choices.D: Employ a second VPN layer concurrently where the other layer's cryptographic implementation is sourced from a different vendor.
choices.B: Subscribe to a managed service provider capable of supporting the mitigation of advanced DDoS attacks on the enterprise's pool of VPN concentrators.
choices.C: Distribute the VPN concentrators across multiple systems at different physical sites to ensure some backup services are available in the event of primary site loss.
choices.A: Implement a reverse proxy for VPN traffic that is defended and monitored by the organization's SOC with near-real-time alerting to administrators.

comments.content: Just guessing at the logic here. If the zero day is specific to one vendor, then shutdown the that specific VPN and use only the other VPN until patch is available and applied?

Going with A. 

What if the 2nd layer VPN from the different vendor has the same zero-day vulnerability? Makes no sense.. Agree with lmao on this one.

discussion.content:
How is using a double VPN supposed to thwart zero day attacks?

Leaning more towards A. here.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester has been contracted to conduct a physical assessment of a site. Which of the following is the MOST plausible method of social engineering to be conducted during this engagement?

choices.D: Obtaining fake government credentials and impersonating law enforcement to gain access to a company facility
choices.A: Randomly calling customer employees and posing as a help desk technician requiring user password to resolve issues
choices.C: Simulating an illness while at a client location for a sales call and then recovering once listening devices are installed
choices.B: Posing as a copier service technician and indicating the equipment had ג€phoned homeג€ to alert the technician for a service call

discussion.content: Its B , conduct a physical assessment, also they have asked for a plausible one. calling the employees is not a part of physical assessment. try an illness will attract too much attention and they will likely send you to a hospital. whereas posing a police officer is not legal
It is definitely not A, this would not give physical access. I think the best answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
Its B. We want to do a physical assessment of the site, so gaining physical access by acting like a copier tech would do it.
B is correct

I say A. "The definition of plausible is something that is highly likely." It is HIGHLY likely someone would pose as a Help Desk Technician requiring user password to resolve issues. Oldest play in the book, taking a chance of actually going to a site and risking the camera capturing your face is not a good idea and it is NOT plausible.
As others already said: the hint is "physical" so B is correct.
B is definitely correct.
What is the actual Answer?

comments.content:
Definitely B.
A has nothing to do with a physical assessment. B will validate that the site is physically secure--if someone shows up claiming to be a copy technician their job and service order should be validated before they're allowed into the building, probably with a badge and definitely signing in at reception.
As stated earlier, simulating illness would not be an effective strategy and impersonating LEO is highly illegal. There is nothing illegal about pretending to fix copy machines.
